Course Glossary


A
abstract

art that doesn't exactly look like real things; it's more about shapes, colors, and feelings

acrylic paint

a water-based, fast-drying paint that can be used thickly or thinly

actual texture

how something feels

analogous

two or more colors that are side by side on the color wheel and often contain the same primary color

animator

an artist who creates moving illustrations like cartoons

anonymous

of unknown identity

appreciation

understanding of the value of something given and an accompanying feeling of thankfulness

architect

a person who designs buildings

art

a creative skill practiced in the form of a drawing, painting, or sculpture

art movement

a tendency or style in art with a specific common philosophy or goal that is followed by a group of artists

art venues

a commercial or nonprofit establishment that is open to the public and in which works of art are sold or displayed

architect

a person who designs buildings and directs their construction

animator

a person who creates or helps to create animated cartoons

ancient

extremely old

apprentice

one who works for another to learn their skill or trade

archaeologist

a person who studies history by examining artifacts from different cultures

automatism

when artwork is created that emphasizes actions and instincts over thoughts and ideas

abstraction

art that does not attempt to represent an accurate depiction of a visual reality

acclaimed

highly praised

assemblage

the art of assembling bits and pieces together to make three-dimensional art

asymmetrical balance

a piece of art that is not balanced

B
Blue Period

artwork created by Pablo Picasso between 1901 and 1904 when he painted with tints and shades of blue and green

branding

a name or symbol that represents a company or idea

bristles

hairs of a paintbrush

bound

held by or tied

background

the part of the image that is farthest from you and seems smaller 

balance

how visual weight is distributed, or organized, in a work of art

bumpy

a surface that is uneven

C
canvas

cloth or material you paint or draw on

consumption

the act or process of using up or consuming

composed

to form or combine into a whole

contemporary

present, current, modern

career

a profession or occupation chosen as a life’s work

caricature

a picture, description, or imitation of a person in which certain striking characteristics are exaggerated in order to create a comic or grotesque effect

cartoonist5

a person who draws cartoons as their job

cast shadow

a shadow created by something blocking the light source

chalk pastel

a stick of compressed powder that's designed to create thicker lines than standard sidewalk chalk

Chiaroscuro

the dramatic contrast of light and dark areas on a painting

commonality

things that are the same or shared between people, groups, or situations

cool colors

colors that give a feeling of cold, such as blue

color wheel

colors arranged in a certain order in the shape of a circle

comic artist

artists who draw scenes telling a story in several panels like a comic book

compliment

an expression of respect or admiration

complementary colors

colors directly opposite from each other on the color wheel

composition

how an artwork is made up or created

conservator

a person who guards or preserves art from harm or decay

conservation

the act of preserving and protecting from loss, destruction, or waste

cone

a three-dimensional shape that has a flat circular base joined to a curved edge that ends in a point

conventional

adhering closely to accepted customs and standards

constructive criticism

to offer both positive and negative comments in a respectful manner

contrast

the arrangement of opposite elements to create visual interest in a work of art

craftsmanship

quality of work in something made by hand

crimp

the part of the ferrule that secures it to the handle

criteria

a standard by which something can be judged

competitive

having an opportunity or desire to win

criticism

pointing out flaws

confine

limited within certain bounds; restricted

cube

a three-dimensional shape with six equal square faces

Cubism

a style of art from the early 20th century that uses geometric shapes

curator

a person who oversees activities and tends the collections of a museum, library, or the like

cylinder

a three-dimensional shape that has two flat circular ends and a curve that joins them

cubism

a style of art from the early 20th century that uses geometric shapes

constructive criticism

to offer both positive and negative comments in a respectful manner

collage

an art technique where different materials are cut or ripped and put together in unexpected ways, often using glue and scissors

carved sculpture

a three-dimensional form that is created by using tools to cut or scrape away at a solid material

cast sculpture

a three-dimensional form that is created when metal is melted down and then poured into a mold

D
decagon

a shape with ten straight lines and ten angles

digital portfolio

a collection of an artist’s best artwork saved to an electronic device

disadvantage

an unfavorable or inferior condition or circumstance

documentary photographer

an artist who uses a camera to keep track of or document events and people important to history and everyday life.

displace

to cause something to move from its usual place

distinctive

clearly marking a person or thing as different from others

distorted proportion

something that is out of proportion, whether on purpose or not

depth

a space technique that makes objects look three-dimensional in two-dimensional artworks

E
elements of art

the building blocks used by artists to create a work of art, such as line, shape, color, value, space, texture, and form

enrich

to cause to be more interesting, important, or rewarding

enable

give someone the ability to do something

evolve

to develop, achieve, or devise gradually

exhibit

to show or display

esteemed

respect or value for another person

engineer

a person who is trained in the use of machines, engines, or technologies

eccentric

a person who behaves in unusual ways

emphasis

the part of an artwork that catches the viewer’s eye by using techniques

earthwork

art that is made by creating forms in nature or with all natural materials

F
fashion designer

a person who designs clothing and accessories

ferrule

the metal part of a paintbrush, connecting the bristles to the handle

folk art

art unique to a particular culture

filmmaker

a person who directs or produces films

flourish

to do well, succeed, prosper

form

a three-dimensional object with length, height, and width

foreground

the part of the image that is closest to you and seems larger

focal point

the part of an artwork that grabs your attention first

full round sculpture

a three-dimensional form that is not attached to any type of flat background

G
graffiti

something written, scratched, or drawn on a wall or the like

gradient

a design element made up of colors that gradually fade into one another, gradients either consist of many shades of the same color, or multiple colors that blend from one to the other

graphic designer

a person who combines images and text to create visual art

geometric shape

a shape that has clear lines and edges

geometric form

a three-dimensional object that can be seen from different perspectives, such as a cube, a sphere, a cylinder, and a cone

H
handle

the part of a paintbrush that is held in a hand

hexagon

a shape with six straight lines and six angles

highlight

an area on an object where light is hitting; to lighten

hypothesize

the action of making a guess based on all the facts available

horizon line

a horizontal line that separates land from sky or sky from water

I
illustrator

a person who creates pictures for magazines and books

immortality

the ability to live forever

implied texture

texture that you can see but cannot touch; a surface that looks like it has texture

impressionism

a style of painting that tries to capture a feeling or mood instead of focusing on making a realistic-looking art piece

intensity

how dull or bright a color is

interactive sculpture

art that relies on participation from the observer

intricate

having many complexly interrelated parts, angles, or aspects; involved; elaborate

irregular geometric shape

2-D shapes where the angles and sides are not all the same size

interior designer

a person who designs the inside of homes and offices

illustrator

an artist who makes illustrations for books or other written works

intricate

having many complex parts

implied form

a two-dimensional representation of a three-dimensional object that appears to have depth

J

K
kabuki

a classical form of Japanese theatre

Kente cloth

colorful, patterned, and handwoven cloth from Ghana

L
line

a path created by a moving point, mark, or object

legend

a story that has been passed on within a culture

loom

a device for weaving fabric

landfill

a location where garbage that cannot be recycled is buried under the earth

M
media

multiple materials used to create a work of art

medium

a material used to create a work of art

migrant

a person who moves away from their usual place of residence, often to find work

mentorship

the influence, guidance, or direction given by a mentor

monument

a structure, statue, or building made to honor a person or special event

morph

to change from one form or state to another; transform

movement

the pathway that a viewer’s eye takes through an artwork

mixed media

artwork composed from a combination of different media or materials

manor house

a house set in a large rural estate with grounds that include manicured lawns, lakes, and woodlands

middle ground

the part of the image that is in the middle 

modeled sculpture

a three-dimensional form that is made when soft material is built up and shaped to create a form

N
non-objective

artwork created with no reference to reality and not inspired by a subject

negative space

the space around the focal point in a work of art; also known as the background 

O
oil pastel

made using an oil and wax binder and has a creamy consistency

ombre

a gradual transition of color

op art

a style of abstract art that creates an optical illusion and tricks the eye

opaque

not allowing light to pass through

organic shape

a flowing and unstructured shape

octagon

a shape with eight straight lines and eight angles

ornate

having much decoration

orphan

a child whose parents have died

organic form

a three-dimensional object that is free-flowing and unstructured

P
palette

a surface for mixing and organizing colors in art

parallel lines

two or more lines that run next to each other

parallelogram

a shape where the opposite sides are parallel and of equal length

pattern

combines different elements which are then repeated

pattern

art that has been made to be displayed outside

perpendicular lines

two lines that cross to form a right angle

philosophy

the study of the nature and principles of knowledge, truth, existence, and moral and aesthetic values

photojournalist

a journalist who communicates news through photographs

pointillism

a technique of painting that uses tiny dots of various colors, which are blended together by the viewer’s eye

polychromatic

a color palette with many colors

portfolio

a collection of an artist’s best artwork

preservation

the act of preserving; protection from loss or damage

pressure

the applying of constant force upon a surface

primary colors

colors that are used to make all other colors on the color wheel (red, yellow, and blue)

principles of design

the ways that artists use the elements of art in a work of art

printmaker

a person who makes prints

propaganda

information or stories shared to try and make people believe or feel a certain way about something

proportion

the size of things in an artwork in relation to other things

public

of, for, or pertaining to all members of a community; not private

pyramid

a large structure with four sides that usually slope upward and meet at a point

positive space

the main focus of a work of art; also known as the foreground

perspective

relating subjects to each other on a flat surface in order to give the illusion of a three-dimensional space

portrait bus

a sculpted or cast representation of the upper part of the human body, depicting a person’s head and neck, as well as part of the chest and shoulders

perseverance

continued effort to do or achieve something despite difficulties, failure, or opposition

Q
quality of life

the standard of health, comfort, and happiness experienced by an individual or group

quadrilateral

a shape with four straight lines and four angles

quilting bee

a social event where women gather to talk to one another while sewing quilts

quoll

a small animal found in Australia and New Guinea

subconscious

information your mind remembers when you are not actively trying to do so

surrealism

an art movement inspired by the subconscious mind and dreams

R
realistic

art that looks just like the real thing – like a photo; artists try to get all the details right so it looks real

rough

a surface that is bumpy or uneven

realistic proportion

something that is in proportion and looks realistic

rhythm

when one or more elements of art are repeated to create a feeling of movement

rhombus

a four-sided shape with equal sides that looks like a diamond

regular geometric shape

2-D shapes where all the angles and sides are the same size

rectangular prism

a three-dimensional shape with six rectangular faces and all equal opposite faces

reflect

to throw back (light, heat, sound, or the like), as from a surface; to cast light back or to cast back light

repetition

the same object being repeated

ritual

an established and prescribed procedure for a ceremony

Rose Period

artwork created by Pablo Picasso between 1904 and 1906 when he painted using warm reds, pinks, and oranges

repurpose

to reuse an unlikely material for the purpose of art

realism

artwork created to appear how it does in real life

role

a responsibility someone takes on, such as a job

relief sculpture

a sculpture that has a two-dimensional, flat background and is designed to be viewed from one side

S
satire

the art of making something or someone look ridiculous or to embarrass

smooth

a surface without roughness, bumps, or ridges

secondary colors

colors made up of two primary colors (green, purple, and orange)

sfumato

an art technique that artists use to gradually blend colors together

sgraffito

a technique of cutting through a top layer to reveal a bottom layer of color

shade

when black is added to a color, it creates a dark value

shadow

an area on an object where light does not hit

sketchbook

a book or place for you to practice your art skills

socioeconomic

a person’s position in society based on income, education, and occupation

speculations

to think about something and make guesses

sphere

a three-dimensional circular object

spirituality

the condition, quality, or fact of being spiritual

stained glass

glass that is colored and used in decorative windows

stippling

to render part or the whole of (a painting, drawing, or engraving) in dots, points, or dabs

strive

to try or work hard

sulphite paper

a thick paper that is almost smooth to the touch and white in color

symbolism

expressing things by means of symbols

symbol

a pattern, image, or design that represents or stands for something else

symbolize

to be a symbol of; to represent by means of a symbol or symbols

scale

the size of an object compared to us or to other objects

surrealist

an artist that attempts to show the subconscious mind with dream imagery or other unusual effects

spikey

something that has one or more sharp points

symmetrical balance

a work of art that is the same on both sides of a center line; a mirror image of something

T
tapestry

a heavy cloth that has designs or pictures woven into it and is used as a wall hanging

tripod

a stand with three legs that is used to support something such as a camera

tempera paint

a type of paint made from pigments (powdered colors), egg yolk, and water that dries quickly

Tenebrism

a style of painting showing very intense chiaroscuro so that darkness overtakes most of a scene

textile

cloth made by weaving or knitting

tertiary colors

colors produced by mixing a primary color and a secondary color

three-dimensional

an object with form that has length, height, and width

thought-provoking

causing or challenging one to think deeply and seriously

tangible

something that can be touched or felt

tint

when white is added to a color, it creates a light value

tone

created when gray is added to a color

transparent

allowing light to pass through

trapezoid

a four-sided shape with one pair of parallel lines

two-dimensional

a flat shape that has length and width

two-point perspective

a drawing method where parallel lines converge toward two vanishing points on the horizon

tenacious

holding on or tending to hold on strongly or persistently

trѐs chic

very stylish

texture

how objects feel, or look like they would feel

transformation

a change in the form, structure, character, or nature of something or someone

U
ukiyo-e

a school of Japanese art depicting subjects from everyday life

utilitarian

an object that has a use or purpose

unity

when all elements of art are working together in harmony

umber

a yellowish-brown or reddish-brown color

unrelated

things that aren’t connected or linked in any way

V
vague

not exact, unclear, or indistinct in form or character

vandalism

willful and malicious destruction or defacement of property or an act thereof

vandalism

willful and malicious destruction or defacement of property or an act thereof

venue

a place where an event is taking place

value scale

a guide to creating a range of value

visual arts

visual arts

variety

the use of more than one element of art to help guide a viewer's eye through an artwork

vanishing point

the point where lines in perspective appear to meet at a single point

W
warm colors

colors that give a feeling of heat, such as orange

wallpaper

paper printed with colors or colored patterns and pasted onto walls and ceilings

watercolor paint

a type of paint that works when mixed with water

watercolor paper

a thick, stiff paper that has a rough or bumpy texture that is often used with watercolor paint and is white in color

weave

to make fabric or baskets by passing threads or strips over and under each other

web designer

a person who designs websites

X

Y

Z
